Graphical abstract The selective hydrogenation of a molecule containing several unsaturated groups is a very important issue and has attracted much more attention in the chemical synthesis. Herein, a highly selective catalyst of Pt-Bi/TiO2 was first time developed for the hydrogenation of 3-nitrostyrene (NS) to 3-aminostyrene (AS), with it an excellent selectivity to AS of 96% was achieved at the complete conversion. The influence of Bi on the catalytic performance was well discussed by using X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electronic microscopy (TEM), CO pulse chemisorption, hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), diffuse reflectance Fourier transform infrared (DRFTIR) spectroscopy of adsorbed CO, and thermo gravimetric analysis (TGA) and experiment data. With increasing Bi loading, Bi-rich surface was formed, and the terraces sites of Pt disappeared as it transferred to the low coordinated Pt gradually. Thus, high selectivity of AS was obtained over Pt-Bi/TiO2 for the hydrogenation of AS to 3-ethylaniline (EA) was lowered. Keywords Selective hydrogenation 3-Nitrostyrene 3-Aminostyrene Pt-Bi/TiO2 1 Introduction Catalytic selectivity is a very important factor for evaluating the performance of catalyst from the view point of atom efficiency in the green and sustainable chemical industrial process [1]. The chemoselective hydrogenation of simple nitroarenes to aromatic amines can be obtained over commercially available catalysts. But, when another reducible group simultaneously present in one molecule, it is difficult to hydrogenate nitro group chemoselectively but not to the other one [2]. Functionalized anilines are important chemicals with wide applications in pharmaceuticals, herbicides, pigments, and other fine chemicals [3]. For example, the selective hydrogenation of nitrostyrene (NS) to aminostyrene (AS) is an important reaction and some progresses have been achieved. Some metal catalysts like Au [2,4–6], Ag [7,8], Fe [9], Co [10,11], Mo [12] were found to present high selectivity to AS >95%. However, these catalysts usually exhibit low activity. For example, the activity of Au/TiO2 was only about 1/20 of that of Pt/TiO2 [13]. Pt catalysts show high activity in the hydrogenation of nitroarenes [14], but Pt was more effective for vinyl group in the hydrogenation of NS, gave a low selectivity to AS [2,13,15,16]. In order to improve the selectivity of AS over Pt catalysts, the researchers developed some strategies such as introducing an additive or modifier to the reaction, for instance: organic thiol [17], ionic liquid [18], hexadecyl(2-hydroxyethyl) -dimethylammonium dihydrogen phosphate [19]. However, the additional modifiers will give rise to the problems like difficult separation, production of toxic waste and equipment corrosion. In some cases, support can modify the active species through strong interaction between metal and support. It reported that the higher selectivity of AS was obtained over Pt/TiO2 (93% at conversion of 95%) [5] and Pt/FeO x (96.5% at conversion of 98.6%) [20], because of Pt sites in corner and step increased as the Pt surface was decorated by TiO x and FeO x , which favored the preferential adsorption of nitro group. In addition, Pt could be modified by Zn for Pt/ZnO [21,22] and Pt-Zn/HPS [23] through electron interaction, and produced AS with high selectivity. In addition, Bi was reported could modify Pt and Pd catalysts to suppress the hydrogenation of vinyl group in the semi-hydrogenation of 2-butyne-1,4-diol and 2-methyl-3-butyn-2-ol [24,25]. Stimulated by the above results, herein, we designed a series of Pt-Bi/TiO2 catalysts and their catalytic performances were studied for the hydrogenation of NS. The influence of Bi on the catalytic performance was discussed in detail by using of XRD, TEM, CO pulse chemisorptions, H2-TPR, XPS, DRFTIR, TGA and experiment data. With it a high selectivity to AS (96%) was obtained at 100% conversion under the mild conditions in water. It was confirmed that the high selectivity of Pt-Bi/TiO2 is due to not only the higher intrinsic activity of hydrogenating nitro group with respect to that of vinyl group, but also the preferential adsorption of NS through nitro group on the low-coordinated Pt sites over the surface of Pt-Bi/TiO2. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation A series of Pt-Bi/TiO2 catalysts were prepared by sequential impregnation using P-25 (Across Organics), H2PtCl6·6H2O and BiCl3 (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent). Firstly, the support was impregnated with an ethylene glycol solution of BiCl3, the mixture was treated with ultrasonic for 0.5h, dried at 200°C for 10h, and calcined in air at 550°C for 4h. Secondly, the obtained powder was impregnated with an aqueous of H2PtCl6·6H2O, the mixture was treated with ultrasonic for 0.5h, dried at 100°C for 10h, calcinated at 450°C for 4h in air flow, and reduced at 450°C for 2h in H2 flow. The loading of Pt was 0.5wt%, and the loading of Bi was 0.5, 1.0, 1.3, 1.5 and 1.9wt%, respectively, so the samples were denoted as Pt-Bi/TiO2-x (x =0.5, 1.0, 1.3, 1.5 and 1.9). The preparation of Pt/TiO2 was similar to the Pt-Bi/TiO2 as described above, except for without the addition of Bi. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Power X-ray diffraction was performed using a Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray diffractometer operating at 40kV and 40mA with Cu Kα (λ=1.5405Å) radiation. 2θ scans were performed from 20° to 90° at a 4°/min speed. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were recorded using a JEOL JEM-2010 instrument with an accelerating voltage of 200kV. The TEM samples were prepared by dispersing the catalyst powder in ethanol under ultrasonic for 10min and then the sample was prepared by dispersing the solution onto a carbon film of copper grid. CO pulse chemisorption was performed on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The catalysts were in-situ reduced in 10% H2/Ar flow (30ml/min) at 450°C for 1h, purged with helium (50ml/min) for 1h at 450°C and finally cooled to 50°C. The flow of 10% CO/He was pulsed over the catalyst until the TCD signal was constant. Hydrogen-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were also performed with a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 equipped with TCD. The TPR was conducted with 100 mg sample in 10% H2/Ar flow (30ml/min) at a heating rate 10°C/min. The hydrogen uptake was monitored by TCD. A cold trap was used to condense water generated from the reduction. For pure Bi2O3, the amount of sample was 2.1mg according its loading in Bi/TiO2-1.9. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on the VG Microtech 3000 Multilab. All binding energies were referred to the C1s peak at 284.6eV of surface adventitious carbon. The surface composition was determined by the peak areas of the corresponding lines using a Shirley type background and empirical cross section factors. The deconvolution of Ti 2p3/2 and Ti 2p1/2 was determined by the separation of 5.7eV with a peak area ratio of 2/1. The deconvolution of Pt 4f7/2 and Pt 4f5/2 was determined by the separation of 3.2eV with a peak area ratio of 4/3, and The deconvolution of Bi 4f7/2 and Bi 4f5/2 was determined by the separation of 5.2eV with a peak area ratio of 4/3. Diffuse reflectance Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (DRFTIR) of CO adsorption was measured by iS50 FT-IR Spectrometer (Nicolet) with an MCT detector. Prior to the measurement, the catalyst was in situ reduced in pure H2 (40ml/min) at 450°C for 1h. Then the sample was cooled down to 30°C and a flow of helium (70ml/min) was fed to remove the residual H2, and a background spectrum was collected. Then, a gas flow of 5% CO/He (70ml/min) was introduced into the chamber for 15min. Finally, the sample was purged by helium (70ml/min) for 20min, and the spectrum was collected based on the above background spectrum. In all cases the spectra were recorded at 30°C. Thermo gravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out using a Mettler Toledo TGA-SDTA851 analyzer (Switzerland) from 50 to 800°C in the nitrogen atmosphere at a heating rate of 5°C/min. The Pt leaching was measured by inductively coupled plasma-optional emission spectrometry (ICP-MS, Thermo Scientific ICAP6000, USA). 2.3 Hydrogenation of 3-nitrostyene The liquid-phase hydrogenation of 3-nitrostyene was carried out in a 50ml Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. In a typical reaction, substrate (0.5mmol), catalyst (50mg) and water (5ml) was added into the reactor, it was sealed and flushed with nitrogen to remove the air, and placed into a water bath preset to the reaction temperature of 85°C for 0.25h. Then, H2 (2MPa) was introduced, the reaction time was recorded when the magnetic stirrer was started. After reaction, the reactor was cooled in ice-water bath and depressurized carefully. The liquid product was extracted with toluene and analyzed by a gas chromatograph (Shimadzu GC-2010, Rtx-5 capillary column) attached with a flame ionization detector using o-xylene as an internal standard, the carbon balance was near 100%. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 XRD, TEM and CO pulse chemisorption The XRD patterns of the supported Pt-Bi/TiO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 . All the checked catalysts gave typical TiO2 diffraction peaks of anatase (JCPDS No. 89-492) and rutile (JCPDS No. 87-0710), no any diffractions of Pt, Bi and Bi2O3 were detected, indicating that Pt and Bi species were highly dispersed on the surface of support with a very small particle size, which is in agreement to the results of TEM. As shown in Fig. 2 , the average particle sizes of Pt and Pt-Bi are 1.4 and 1.7nm for Pt/TiO2 and Pt-Bi/TiO2-1.5, respectively, which is in agreement with the results of CO chemisorptions (Table 1 ). In addition, it is clear that with increasing of Bi content, the Pt dispersion decreased from 93.9% to 47.9%, the specific area of Pt decreased from 231.8 to 118.4m2/g, and Pt particle size increased from 1.2 to 2.4nm. Furthermore, from STEM-EDS images of Pt-Bi/TiO2-1.5, Bi and Pt are homogeneously dispersed on the surface of TiO2 (Fig. 2c). 3.1.2 H2 TPR Fig. 3 shows the TPR profiles of the catalysts. For Pt/TiO2 (Fig. 3a), the peak at 79°C was ascribed to the reduction of PtOx (including PtO, Pt2O3 and PtO2) to Pt0, and the second peak around 260°C was ascribed to the partial reduction of TiO2 to TiO x (x< 2) [26,27]. The hydrogen spillover from Pt nanoparticles to the surface of TiO2 resulted in the partial reduction of TiO2 at a low temperature. For Bi/TiO2-1.9 (Fig. 3g), a broaden peak appeared around 240°C, which could be ascribed to the reduction of Bi2O3. TiO2 cannot be reduction without Pt (Fig. 3i), and the reduction of pure Bi2O3 need a much high temperature of 528°C (Fig. 3h), the low reduction temperature of Bi/TiO2-1.9 could be ascribed to the high dispersion of Bi2O3 on TiO2. For the samples of Pt-Bi/TiO2 with different loadings of Bi (Fig. 3b–f), only one main reduction peak presented around 80–85°C, and the peak position moved slightly to the higher temperature with increasing of Bi loading. It indicates Bi2O3 near to Pt particles could be reduced at the lower temperature as some dissociated active hydrogen species spilled from metallic Pt to the near surface of Bi2O3. However, the peak area was not proportional to the loading of Pt and Bi, this phenomenon might ascribe to the reduction occurred somewhat at the temperature lower than the signal recorded at 50°C, it is well known that PtO x could be readily reduced even at room temperature [28]. Furthermore, the hydrogen spillover occurs from Pt most likely to Bi2O3 but very less to TiO2 on the surface of Pt-Bi/TiO2. 3.1.3 XPS Fig. 4 shows the XPS spectra of Pt/TiO2 and Pt-Bi/TiO2 catalysts. The Ti 2p3/2 spectra could be deconvoluted two peaks for all catalysts, the binding energy of 458.9eV was assigned to Ti4+, and that of 458.3eV assigned to Ti x + (3< x< 4) of the partial reduction of TiO2 [29]. For the Pt 4f spectra, the binding energies of 70.4 and 73.6eV were assigned to Pt 4f7/2 and Pt 4f5/2 of Pt0, respectively, and they did not change with the presence of Bi. But the binding energy of Pt 4f7/2 (70.4eV) of Pt/TiO2 and Pt-Bi/TiO2 was lower than that (71.0eV) of the bulk Pt metal, which suggested electron transferred from TiO x (x< 2) to the metal surface [29], resulting in electron-riched Pt and Pt-Bi nanoparticles on the surface of Pt/TiO2 and Pt-Bi/TiO2, respectively. TiO x (x ≤2) could migrate to the surface of Pt [30], which may also occur for the present Pt-Bi/TiO2 catalyst, but the effect on the catalytic performance may be the same to Pt/TiO2 due to the similar electron interaction of TiO x to Pt for both the Pt/TiO2 and Pt-Bi/TiO2. The Bi 4f spectra of Pt-Bi/TiO2 could be deconvoluted two pairs of peak as shown in Fig. 4(III). The peaks at binding energies of 156.6 and 161.8eV were assigned to Bi 4f7/2 and Bi 4f5/2 of Bi0 [31], and that of 158.8 and 164.1eV were assigned to Bi 4f7/2 and Bi 4f5/2 of Bi2O3 [32,33]. The binging energies of Bi 4f7/2 were very close to their standard bulk sample, indicating the electron interaction between Bi and Pt was very weak, which may be due to the strong interaction between TiO2 and Pt, and the formation of intermetallic compound as described below. For Pt-Bi/TiO2-1.5, after Ar+ ion sputtering, the Ti 2p3/2 spectra could be deconvoluted three peaks as shown in Fig. 4(I). The binding energies of 458.9eV was assigned to Ti4+ [29], that of 457.1eV was assigned to Ti3+ [34], and 454.9eV was assigned to Ti2+ [35]. Pt 4f7/2 moved to higher binding energy of 70.9eV from 70.3eV, and the Bi 4f7/2 of Bi2O3 disappeared, which suggested Bi was oxided somewhat on the surface when the sample exposing to air, which will cover the interaction between Pt and Bi on the surface. The atomic ratio of Bi/Pt calculated by XPS (B) was larger than the theoretical values (A) as listed in Table 2 , except for the Pt-Bi/TiO2-0.5 (entry 2), and the ratio of B/A increased with Bi content from 1.0% to 1.9% (entries 3-6). It indicates that Bi covered on the surface of Pt and intermetallic compounds might form according to the phase diagram (Fig. S1) and literature [36]. For Pt-Bi/TiO2-0.5, the weight percent of Pt/(Pt+Bi) of 50% was a little larger than that of BiPt intermetallic compound (48.3%), and B was smaller than A, so BiPt intermetallic compound was formed as core, and the surface of nanoparticles was Pt-rich (entry 2). For Pt-Bi/TiO2-1.0, the weight percent of Pt/(Pt+Bi) of 33.3% was between that of BiPt (48.3%) and γBi2Pt (31.8%) intermetallic compound, and B was larger than A, indicated the surface was Bi-rich, and the core was the mixture of BiPt and γBi2Pt intermetallic compound (entry 3). While for Pt-Bi/TiO2-1.3, 1.5, 1.9, the weight percent of Pt/(Pt+Bi) (27.8%, 25%, 20.8%) were smaller than that of γBi2Pt intermetallic compound (31.8%), and B was much larger than A, indicated the surface was Bi-rich, and the core was γBi2Pt intermetallic compound (entry 4–6). With increasing Bi loading, the Bi content on the surface of nanoparticles increased (entries 2–6), the surface was Bi-rich and the accumulation degree of Bi increased (entries 3–6). 3.1.4 FTIR-CO probe analysis In order to further explore the structure of Pt-Bi/TiO2 catalysts, the adsorption of CO was studied by DRFTIR, and the results are shown in Fig. 5 . For Pt/TiO2, the absorbance peaks at 2090 and 2066cm−1 were related to terminal CO adsorbed on terraces and low-coordinated Pt sites (edges, corners and kinks) [38,39]. The absorbance peak at 1826cm−1 was assigned to bridge-absorbed CO bound on Pt particles [5,40]. For Pt-Bi/TiO2-0.5 (Fig. 5b), the absorbance peak of terminal CO bound on terrace sites red-shifted from 2090 to 2080cm−1, the peak of terminal CO bound on low-coordinated sites shifted from 2066 to 2057cm−1, and the peak of bridge-absorbed CO bound on Pt surface at 1826cm−1 disappeared could be ascribed to the dilution of Bi. With the further increasing of Bi content up to 1.0% (Fig. 5c–f), the absorbance peaks of terminal CO bound on terraces disappeared, which could be ascribed to the dilution of Bi and Pt was covered by Bi species. The red-shift of terminal CO absorbance peak could ascribe to the geometric effect [41,42] that the dilution of Bi would decrease the effect of dipole-dipole coupling between adsorbed CO molecules [43,44]. The results indicated terrace sites changed to low-coordinated sites gradually. 3.2 Catalytic performance The hydrogenation of 3-nitrostyrene (NS) can produce 3-aminostyrene (AS) and 3-ethylnitrobenzene (ENB) by hydrogenation of nitro and vinyl group, respectively, and then produce 3-ethylaniline (EA) via the further hydrogenation of the remained unsaturated bond as shown in Scheme 1 . As the results shown in Table 3 , the selectivity to AS was only 19.8% over Pt/TiO2 due to the formed AS was easily further hydrogenated to EA (entry 1). With addition of Bi (0.5%), the selectivity of AS increased to 43.8% at the similar conversion around 68%, but the activity decreased (entry 2). With increasing of Bi content, the selectivity of AS increased and it reached 96.2% when Bi content increased to 1.0% (entry 3), it changed slightly with the further increasing of Bi content to 1.9% (entries 4–6), while the activity decreased further. With extending reaction time, the conversion of NS reached 100%, and the selectivity to AS kept at 96% over Pt-Bi/TiO2-1.5 (Fig. 6 ), indicating the hydrogenation of AS to EA was prohibited. With addition of Bi, BiPt and/or γBi2Pt intermetallic compounds were formed with surface enriched Bi species, resulting in terrace sites changed to low coordinated Pt sites gradually. The low coordinated Pt sites favor the adsorption of nitro group [5], and the terrace sites favor the adsorption of vinyl group of NS. So the decrease of terrace Pt sites could prohibit the hydrogenation of AS to EA. Hence, the selectivity increased with Bi content (entries 1–3), and maintained at 96% even after complete conversion of NS (Fig. 6). The activity decreased with increasing of Bi content due to the active species of Pt was covered by inert Bi. In order to further investigate the effect of Bi on the catalytic performance over Pt-Bi/TiO2 catalysts, the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene (NB) and styrene (ST) was carried out separately (Table 4 ). The reaction rate of NB (1127h−1) was much higher than that of ST (159h−1) (entries 1, 2). For the hydrogenation of the mixture of NB and ST, although both the reaction rate was lower than their sole hydrogenation, the reaction rate (497h−1) of NB was larger than that (35h−1) of ST (entry 3). The differences in the reaction rate of NB and ST in their mixture is much larger than the cases of their single hydrogenation, indicating NB was preferred to adsorb on the surface of Pt-Bi/TiO2-1.5 by comparing to ST. By contrast, over Pt/TiO2, the much higher reaction rate presented for both the nitrobenzene and styrene, and the difference between them decreased (entry 4), indicating Pt/TiO2 was less selective compared to Pt-Bi/TiO2-1.5. Finally, the catalyst stability of Pt-Bi/TiO2-1.5 was checked (Fig. 7 ). In the first run, a high selectivity to AS of 97% was obtained at a high conversion of 94.9%. At the second run, under the same reaction conditions the conversion decreased seriously to 32.4% with a slight decrease of selectivity (93.2%). For the heterogeneous catalyst, the leaching of the metal species is usually one of the main reasons to induce deactivation. In this work, the Pt leaching was only 0.08% (relative to the initial amount of Pt) as detected by ICP analysis, and the conversion could be recovered to 85.9% after the catalyst was regenerated in H2 flow at 450°C for 2h, indicating the leaching was not the main reason for the loss of activity. Then, we checked the carbon deposit by TGA and the results showed the mass-loss of the used catalyst was only 0.86% at temperatures of 50–800°C (Fig. S2), indicating the carbon deposit was not the main reason of the deactivation either. In addition, the homogeneous dispersion of Pt and Bi on the surface of TiO2 didn’t change after reaction from the STEM-EDS images (Fig. 2d). Finally, we examined the changes of surface composition and metal states by XPS measurement (Fig. 8 ). Compared with the fresh catalyst, the binding energy of Ti 2p3/2 assigned to Ti x + disappeared, and the peak of Pt 4f7/2 assigned to Pt0 shifted to 70.9eV, similar to that of the bulk Pt. However, accompanying with the disappearance of the peaks of Bi 4f7/2 of metallic Bi and Bi2O3, a new peak appeared at binding energy of 159.9eV, which could be assigned to Bi 4f7/2 of BiO(OH) [31]. These may be ascribed to that TiO x was oxided to TiO2, and Bi was oxided to Bi2O3 and then hydrated to BiO(OH) in the presence of NS and H2O, which may be the similar to the case of NiOOH formation in the aqueous hydrogenation of NB over Ni/TiO2 [45]. Moreover, the surface metal ratio of Bi/Pt changed largely during recycling, it increased from 4.95 to 25.6 (Table 2, entries 5, 8), suggesting much more Bi moved and covered onto the surface of active Pt sites, which reduced the activity of the catalyst. After regeneration via heating treatment under the H2 flow, the activity could be recovered as the surface composition and metal states (binding energy of Ti 2p3/2, Pt 4f7/2 and Bi 4f7/2) was restored (Table 2, entry 9 and Fig. 8a, c). 4 Conclusions In conclusion, a highly efficient Pt-Bi/TiO2 catalyst was designed for the selective hydrogenation of 3-nitrostyrene (NS) to 3-aminostyrene (AS). Pt-Bi/TiO2-1.5 exhibited excellent selectivity toward the target product of AS (96%) at the complete conversion of NS. With increasing of Bi loading, more and more Bi covered onto the active Pt sites, forming BiPt and/or γBi2Pt intermetallic compound with surface enriched Bi species, lowered the activity of Pt-Bi/TiO2 catalysts. Moreover, with addition of Bi, the terrace sites transferred to the low coordinated sites of Pt gradually, the former favors of the adsorption of vinyl group but the latter favors of the adsorption of nitro group of NS, thus the selectivity of EA was reduced and the high selectivity of AS (96%) was achieved. The strategy of designing selective catalyst for the competitive hydrogenation of nitro and vinyl group in this work will benefit for the researchers to develop efficient heterogeneous catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The selective hydrogenation of a molecule containing several unsaturated groups is a very important issue and has attracted much more attention in the chemical synthesis. Herein, a highly selective catalyst of Pt-Bi/TiO2 was first time developed for the hydrogenation of 3-nitrostyrene (NS) to 3-aminostyrene (AS), with it an excellent selectivity to AS of 96% was achieved at the complete conversion. The influence of Bi on the catalytic performance was well discussed by using X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electronic microscopy (TEM), CO pulse chemisorption, hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), diffuse reflectance Fourier transform infrared (DRFTIR) spectroscopy of adsorbed CO, and thermo gravimetric analysis (TGA) and experiment data. With increasing Bi loading, Bi-rich surface was formed, and the terraces sites of Pt disappeared as it transferred to the low coordinated Pt gradually. Thus, high selectivity of AS was obtained over Pt-Bi/TiO2 for the hydrogenation of AS to 3-ethylaniline (EA) was lowered.
coredata.dc:title: Chemoselective hydrogenation of 3-nitrostyrene to 3-aminostyrene over Pt-Bi/TiO2 catalysts
